Additional XPath Data 2:
AILSA CRAIG
zw17
Very large, round, to broadish-round Spanish onion for summer. If propagated early enough will provide a high yield. For this, sow under cover in January and transplant outdoors in April-May. Can be stored until December.
Fruit shape: round

Additional XPath Data 2:
FIOLA KS (SAT15)
zw50
Early variety with a very round shape and a fine neck. American-style onions for medium-long storage. Firm and bronze-colored shell. Early ripening, which is advantageous if there is likelihood of late fungus. Bred by Sativa.
Fruit shape: round

Additional XPath Data 2:
ISHIKURA LONG WHITE
zw19
Does not grow onion-bulbs, but instead long, thick shafts. Suitable for bunching. If grown overwinter, ready in spring; if sown in summer, ready in autumn. Tolerant against thrip infestations. Very frost-hardy.

Additional XPath Data 2:
PEAR SHAPED
 zw20
Traditional, yellow-skinned variety from Franconia. Can be directly sown or planted from sets. Bulbs elongated, somewhat reminiscent of a pear-shape. Sweeter than most other Spanish onions.
Fruit shape: high-round

Additional XPath Data 2:
RED BARON
zw30
This round to highly round, bolt-proof variety has a dark red skin and is better to store compared to other red varieties. Its slightly piquant taste makes it versatile to use and it produces a good yield when harvested medium early.
Fruit shape: flat-round

RIJNSBURG SELECTION (SAT24)
zw58
Round, slightly angular onion. Cross of an old flat variety with a traditional pear-shaped variety. Almost the same taste as shallots. Selected for high dry matter, therefore long shelf life. Good mildew resistance.
Fruit shape: round

zw56
